vious that this kind of flexibility can be
extremely useful for local Community Action
Agencies, for such program support areas as
Staff Training and Orientation, for Basic
Education support programs.
There are over 200 channels available in this
spectrum, out of which only 88 have been
applied for, and only 12 have been approved
for operation and are on the air.
While this means that a Community Action Agency,
with its non-profit status, could qualify as an
applicant for the ITFS capability, under FCC
regulations, it is not considered feasible that
they become involved, unless they could develop
some other funding sources which would support
such a venture.
Copies of the FCC Rules and Regulations (Current
Revised) are available from that agency. Specific
questions can be answered by addressing inquiries
to the Community Services Division of CAP in
Washington.
In order to more fully understand the kinds of
